questions.question: Which of the following correctly lists the layers of the sclera from outermost to innermost?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Episclera > Sclera proper > Lamina fusca Explanation: The sclera consists of three ill-defined layers, namely the sclera proper with the episclera on the outside and the lamina fusca interiorly . Layers of the Sclera: Layer Description Composition Remarks Episclera Thin vascularized. connective tissue. Collagen fibers Fibroblasts Blood vessels Nerves Located just outside the sclera proper Sclera proper Relatively avascular. Dense tissue. Dense irregular bundles of collagen (compared to the orderly arrangement in the cornea) Elastic fibers Fibroblasts, Proteoglycans The thickest layer of the sclera Provides structural support and integrity Lamina fusca Innermost layer. Loose connective tissue layer. Melanocytes (migrated from choroid) It contains pigmented cells derived from the choroid

questions.question: Match the scleral apertures with the structures they transmit Scleral Apertures Structures Transmitted A. Anterior scleral apertures 1. Short and long ciliary arteries apertures 3. Anterior ciliary arteries and veins D. Lamina cribrosa 4. Vortex veins
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2 Explanation: The anterior scleral apertures transmit the anterior ciliary arteries and veins , while the middle scleral apertures allow passage for the vortex veins . The posterior scleral apertures transmit the short and long ciliary arteries . The Lamina cribrosa is where the central retinal artery and vein enter the sclera. Apertures of the sclera: Apertures Location Structures transmitted Anterior 3-4 mm posterior to the limbus Anterior ciliary vessels, nerves, and lymphatics Middle 4 to 7 mm behind the equator 4 vortex veins (Vena verticose) Posterior Around the optic nerve 8 to 20 short ciliary vessels (circle of Zinn) and nerves 2 long posterior ciliary arteries anterior to short ciliary Lamina cribrosa Posterior most Optic nerve fibers Central retinal artery and veins.

A 40-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of episcleritis. After taking a detailed history and performing a thorough systemic examination, which of the following investigations would you consider ordering?

options.A: Full blood count and rheumatoid factor (RF)
options.C: VDRL and X-rays of the chest and sacroiliac joints

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Episcleritis can be associated with systemic conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis (RF), systemic lupus erythematosus (ANA), and other systemic infections or inflammatory diseases that may be assessed with the Mantoux test ( Tuberculosis ) and VDRL ( Syphilis ). X-rays of the chest and sacroiliac joints can help rule out conditions like ankylosing spondylitis, which can also present with episcleritis. Therefore, a comprehensive approach including all listed investigations is appropriate. Conditions associated with Episcleritis: Idiopathic : The exact etiology is unknown in many cases. Systemic Diseases : Gout Rosacea Psoriasis Connective tissue diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, lupus) Hypersensitivity Reactions : Endogenous tubercular toxins Streptococcal toxins Infectious Episcleritis : Herpes zoster virus Syphilis Lyme disease Tuberculosis Reference: Parson’s Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Page 200. Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page 292

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman with a 15-year history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) presents with severe ocular pain, redness, and progressively worsening vision in her left eye for the past 2 weeks. Examination reveals a localized area of scleral thinning with adjacent congestion. There is no posterior involvement on B-scan ultrasound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Necrotizing scleritis with inflammation Explanation: Severe pain, scleral thinning with adjacent congestion are hallmark signs of necrotizing scleritis , the most severe form of RA-associated scleritis. RA leads to immune-mediated vasculitis , causing ischemic necrosis of the sclera . Classification of Scleritis: Anterior Staphyloma (Option A): Anterior staphyloma is a late-stage complication, where uveal tissue bulges through a thinned, scarred sclera. This patient has active inflammation, whereas staphyloma occurs after chronic necrosis and healing. Nodular Scleritis (Option C): Nodular scleritis presents with discrete, firm nodules on the sclera, without necrosis. This patient has scleral thinning and avascular necrosis, which rules out nodular scleritis. Scleromalacia Perforans (Option D): Scleromalacia perforans is a form of necrotizing scleritis WITHOUT inflammation (painless, non-red eye). This patient has severe pain and congestion, so active necrotizing scleritis is the correct choice.

questions.question: A 38-year-old male presents with persistent eye discomfort, redness, and watering. On examination, the left eye is diffusely tender, sclera appears uniformly reddened and swollen without localized thinning areas. There are no systemic signs of vasculitis or autoimmune disease on further investigation. Which type of anterior scleritis is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Non-necrotizing anterior diffuse scleritis Explanation: Clinical presentation of persistent eye discomfort, watering, diffuse redness, and tenderness without localized necrosis or thinning is characteristic of non-necrotizing anterior diffuse scleritis. Anterior Scleritis: Most common in elderly female patients ( 40-70 years) Etiology : Associated with connective tissue disease (50% of cases) Clinical classification: Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis Diffuse Nodular Necrotizing anterior scleritis With inflammation Without inflammation Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis: Pain, redness, watering, discharge, and bluish or brownish discoloration. Nodular: One or more dark red or bluish nodules, which later become purple and semitransparent like porcelain. (Option C ruled out) Diffuse ( most common ): Diffuse or localized congestion (Option B) Treatment: First-line Topical steroids eye drops Oral NSAIDs Second-line Systemic steroids Necrotizing anterior scleritis: Necrosis of sclera Severe thinning, and melting in severe cases With inflammation: (Option A ruled out) Severe form of scleritis Red, painful eye, and progressive worsening of symptoms Without inflammation (Scleromalacia perforans): (Option D ruled out) Painless scleral thinning Treatment: Topical steroids eye drops High dose of oral steroids Non-responsive cases Immunosuppressive agents Surgical treatment: scleral patch graft in severe cases to preserve the integrity of the globe due to severe thinning and melting.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with severe pain in her right eye, worsened by eye movements, and reduced vision. On examination, proptosis and restricted ocular movements were observed. Ophthalmoscopy shows disc, macular edema, and choroidal folds. Which of the following B-scan ultrasonography findings is most indicative of this disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) T sign Explanation: Given the clinical presentation of severe pain in the eye, proptosis, restricted ocular movements, reduced vision, disc, and macular edema, and the potential findings of choroidal folds, the diagnosis most consistent with these symptoms is posterior scleritis . Thickening of the posterior sclera, retrobulbar thickening, and fluid surrounding the optic nerve creates a characteristic “T” sign in B-scan ultrasound. Posterior scleritis: Inflammation with thickening of the posterior sclera Clinical manifestations: Decreased vision, with or without pain Proptosis Restricted ocular movements Posterior vitiates Disc and macular oedema Choroidal folds Choroidal detachment Uveal effusion syndrome Exudative retinal detachment Diagnosis: USG-B scan shows T sign (Pathognomonic finding): (Option A) It represents the fluid accumulation between the optic nerve and the sclera It is the name given to the shape of the scleral thickening: Each arm of the T represents the posterior sclera with the stem as the optic nerve. Others-CT, MRI Treatment: Systemic NSAIDs Systemic steroids Immunosuppressive therapy Biologics: Infliximab and rituximab Moth-Eaten Appearance (Option B) : Seen in Retinoblastoma , characterized by intraocular calcifications , typically in children , not adults. Sunray Sign (Option C) : Seen in Choroidal Melanoma , due to radial vascularity , but this patient lacks an intraocular mass . Kiss Sign (Option D) : Seen in Total Retinal Detachment , where the detached retina folds inward , but this case has no retinal involvement .

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman with a 20-year history of rheumatoid arthritis has a painless, progressively thinning area in the sclera of her left eye. The area appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Type III hypersensitivity Explanation: The diagnosis in this scenario is scleromalacia perforans. It is usually associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and presents with scleral thinning appearing bluish and without signs of inflammation. The underlying cause of scleral thinning is probably ischemia because of vessel damage ( type III hypersensitivity ). Scleromalacia Perforans: Most common in elderly females. Pathophysiology: Associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. Melting of the sclera is due to obliteration of arterial supply causing ischemia. Vessel damage is mediated by type III hypersensitivity. Clinical manifestations: Painless scleral thinning Underlying dark uveal tissue is visible Rarely perforation of the globe Treatment: No specific therapy Protection of the eye from trauma is very crucial Plenty of topical lubrication Oral NSAIDs Oral steroids Immunomodulatory agents Surgery-scleral patch grafting Reference: Parson’s Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Page 527 Scleromalacia Perforans - EyeWiki

questions.question: Depending on the location of the staphyloma in the eye which among the following options is matched correctly with its cause?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Equatorial staphyloma - scleritis Explanation: The causes of equatorial staphyloma are scleritis , degenerative myopia, and chronic uncontrolled glaucoma. Staphyloma: It is ectasia of the outer coats of the eye (cornea, sclera, or both) with an incarceration of the uveal tissue. Based on the site affected, staphyloma can be classified as: Types of staphyloma Causes Anterior (Option A ruled out) Pseudocornea Intercalary (Option B ruled out) Perforating injuries of the peripheral cornea, marginal corneal ulcer, anterior scleritis, and scleromalacia perforans Ciliary (Option D ruled out) Glaucoma, scleritis, and trauma to the ciliary region Equatorial (approx 14 mm behind the limbus) (Option C) Scleritis, degenerative myopia, and chronic uncontrolled glaucoma Posterior Degenerative high axial myopia Treatment: Treat underlying condition Local excision and repair with a corneal and scleral patch graft Large staphyloma: Staphylectomy and keratoplasty, or enucleated and replaced with an implant

questions.question: Blue sclera is commonly associated with all of the following conditions except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Alkaptonuria Explanation: Yellow-brown or blue-black pigment deposition occurs in different parts of the eye in alkaptonuria. Classic scleral pigment deposits are called “Osler’s sign. Blue sclera: Uveal pigment shines through the thin sclera and produces the blue color Causes: Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option A ruled out) Ehlers–Danlos syndrome (Option B ruled out) Marfan syndrome (Option D ruled out) Pseudoxanthoma elasticum Scleromalacia perforans Reference: Parson’s Diseases of the eye, 23rd Edition, Pages 534-35 Ocular Manifestations of Alkaptonuria - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)
